headline: Good culture, but quite traditional

They don't fire people. If you care about job security, this company is THE ONE. They could transfer you around until you get sick of your job, but they don't fire people. Public Bank honours LOYALTY.

The bonus and benefits (staff/car loans, medical) are great. Lots of leave as per industry standard.

Hardworking, sweet people. They really work well with one another to ensure everything runs smoothly. They're quite patient and willing to teach you anything you want/need to know. 

Low-risk, conservative and very safe! You can expect Public Bank to tide through bad economic times without a hitch. It's quite amazing how resilient they are when times are tough.
cons:
Really outdated systems. A lot of manual work, paperwork, and inefficiencies in the system such as keying in the same data multiple times, even within the same form!

Cost cutting can lead to really bad backlog or high overtime without any form of compensation. Even when requesting for additional staff with sufficient justification, it is rarely granted.

Both of the above lead to: No work life balance. You'll pretty much be stuck in the office overtime, early, on weekends, trying to clear your unending pile forever. It's not tough work, but the volume gets quite overwhelming.

headline: It's a good stepping stone for fresh graduates.
pros:
- It's a good training ground for fresh graduates who aspire to work in the banking/financial services industry. The job scope as a Graduate Trainee (GT) - Credit Analyst isn't that demanding, more so repetitive. It's basically a glorified data entry job. 

- Salary was alright but it's at the lower end compared to what other banks are offering. 

- Benefits such as 24 days annual leave, unlimited medical claims (only through panel clinics/hospitals), cheaper car/housing loan rate, staff credit cards with no annual fees. 

- They do provide free training for newcomers, equipping them with knowledge about the banking laws and regulations
cons:
- NO CAREER ADVANCEMENT.   If you join Public Bank as a Graduate Trainee - Credit Analyst, you're pretty much stuck at the same position and doing the same thing until you reach retirement...no joke. It's easier to move up the corporate ladder if you do sales.  

- No OT.   We were expected to work until 9pm everyday while unable to claim for OT. 

- A LOT OF RED TAPES/ UNNECESSARY OBSTACLES JUST TO MAKE SLIGHTLY WORK UNBEARABLE . 

- LACK OF APPRECIATION.    

NOTE:
=====

If you're given a chance to join Public Bank as a Trainee Credit Analyst, use this opportunity as a stepping stone in your career life. They love to hire international graduates to do menial tasks with no show of appreciation/guidance and wonder why turnover is very high.
